fields.description:
h4. Problem
Since version 3.8.0 of Stash the {{server.xml}} configuration file has been moved to {{<Stash home directory> /shared/server.xml}}. Previously this was located at {{<Stash installation directory>/conf/server.xml}}.

STP, when generating the support.zip will include the {{server.xml}} file from both locations, without indicating which one is effective.

h4. Suggestion
Include only the file that is used or indicate which version is being picked up by Bitbucker Server, if there is more than one file in the generated support.zip

Related issue for STP: https://ecosystem.atlassian.net/browse/STP-353
fields.summary: Support Tools Plugin may include two versions of server.xml
Exception thrown in event listener for RepositoryDeletedRequestedEvent rolls back transaction

fields.description: A sidebar feed for all new commits to Repositories under specific projects. So you can see new commits being made each specific Repository
fields.summary: commit Feed

fields.description:
We use git flow model of branching.
Branch master - production,
branch release (only one) - candidate to production,
and branch develop - new features.
Auto merging is switch on.
We use hotfix to correct production errors. After pull request we expect auto merge to release and develop. We've got only auto merge to develop.
I've read BSERV-7235 and I've feeling that branching model of stash is not git flow.
Is possible change configuration to support git flow?
fields.summary: Pull request in master branch should be merged in develop branch

fields.description:
h4. Problem
BitBucket Server utilizes the System Info View. When it comes to rendering this page, on an instance with large number of projects/repositories, the size of the generated request can grow to a large extent, in some cases resulting in out of memory errors.

h4. Workaround
- Analyze the heap dump and identify if the heap is utilized to a class named - {{org.apache.catalina.connector.Response}}, which is initiated by the STP (Support Tools Plugin).
- Verify that the instance has a large number of repositories and other metadata rendered on the System Info View (or by the {{application.xml}} file in the Support Zip).

If the above two is present, the workaround is to increase the heap allocation, so that the response can fit into memory.
fields.summary: Support Tools Plugin System Info View excessive memory usage

fields.description: Currently Embedded Crowd in Bitbucket Server acts as a pass-through for authentication to LDAP servers.  This places load on the network and the LDAP server.  To reduce load, cache the credentials in Embedded Crowd so that Bitbucket Server does not need to contact the LDAP server.
fields.summary: Cache LDAP credentials in Bitbucket Server

fields.description:
For me as a server Admin it is a must to get urgent system notifications by mail.
i.E. the Message, which showed to all users in a red bar on the server.
{noformat}
Bitbucket erreicht die Ressourcengrenzen. Pushes, Pulls, das Mergen von Pull Requests und Klons werden eventuell zurückgewiesen oder in die Warteschlange gestellt. Details für Scaling Bitbucket Server ansehen
or
Stash is reaching ressource limits. Pushes, pulls, pull requests merges and clones may be rejected or queued. 
{noformat}
 !screenshot-11.png! 
We currently are informed by the user.
Please change bitbucket correspond to that administrators will be informed of messages which the users also get displayed on the Bitbucket Server page.

Thanks
Martin

fields.description:
As of BitBucket Server v4.1.0:

In the Branching Model section of Repository settings we can set branch prefixes for BranchTypes (Bugfix, Feature, Hotfix, Release). This prefix cannot be obtained via the Java API.

In the API, we can obtain a BranchType (com.atlassian.bitbucket.branch.model.BranchType), which only exposes the methods {{getDisplayName()}} and {{getId()}}.

However, a REST call to {{STASH_HOME/rest/branch-utils/1.0/projects/project/repos/repo/branchmodel}} results in the resulting JSON: 

{"development": ... ,"types": [{"id":"BUGFIX","displayName":"Bugfix","prefix":"bugfix/"}, ... ]}

Notice the element in the "types" array has an {{id}}, {{displayName}}, *and* {{prefix}}: the Java API doesn't expose the same information as the REST API. It would make sense to unify their capabilities.

The suggestion then is to expose a {{getPrefix()}} method.
fields.summary: BranchType Java API should expose getPrefix()

fields.description:
It is very common to want to CI build/test the merged result of a PR.

While Stash show's the build status of commits, and will show the build status for the HEAD commit of */pr/$\{pullRequestId\}/from on the PR page, it would be great be able to show the build status for the HEAD commit of */pr/$\{pullRequestId\}/merge on the PR page.

https://developer.atlassian.com/stash/docs/latest/how-tos/updating-build-status-for-commits.html#Viewing_build_results
https://developer.atlassian.com/static/rest/stash/3.11.3/stash-build-integration-rest.html

A REST API to PUT a build status for a CommitId /rest/build-status/1.0/commits/\{commitId\} exists, and this will work for the HEAD commit of */pr/$\{pullRequestId\}/from. It might be nice if that also worked and displayed for HEAD commit of */pr/$\{pullRequestId\}/merge.

Alternatively the Build Status of a PR could be considered as distinct from the Build Status of a Commit, and 
/rest/api/1.0/projects/\{projectKey\}/repos/\{repositorySlug\}/pull-requests/\{pullRequestId\}
extended with a '/build-status' API to set this status.
fields.summary: Show Build Status for Pull Request merge

fields.description: From Stash 2.10 to Bitbucket Server 4.0, {{PluginSettings.put(key, "")}} would delete {{key}} from plugin settings.  In 4.1.0 it raises {{java.lang.IllegalArgumentException}}.
fields.summary: PluginSettings.put(key, "") should remove the key

fields.description:
h3. Summary

When clicking or saving from the "Raw file" link in Bitbucket Server's source view, the extension is ignored and the file saves/displays as .txt.


h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Open a {{.sql}} file in Source View
# Right-click "Raw file"
# Select "Save as"
# Save file

h3. Expected Results

File is saved as {{.sql}}

h3. Actual Results

File is saved as {{.sql.txt}} or {{.txt}}
 
h3.Workaround

Clone/Check out the repo and access the file via git
fields.summary: Saving Raw file from source view always downloads as .txt by default

{noformat}

{noformat}

h3. Steps to Reproduce

# Push your changes to Bitbucket Server.
# View the path in the Bitbucket Server UI.

The source and diff are rendered correctly.

Anything after the {{;}} in the path is truncated. Therefore, if your filename is {{test.pkb;plb}} for example, Bitbucket Server will run a git call for {{test.pkb}}.

There is no known workaround at this time, with the exception of not using semicolons in filenames.

h3. Summary
The HipChat plugin connection fails when using SQL Server database in the following scenarios:
# when upgrading to Bitbucket server 4.1.0 or 4.0.4
# when installing Bitbucket server 4.1.0 or 4.0.4

h3. Environment
The issue only occurs when Bitbucket is connected to a SQL Server database

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Install/Upgrade Bitbucket server 4.1.0 or 4.0.4
# [Connect Bitbucket Server to SQL Server|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver/connecting-bitbucket-server-to-sql-server-776640385.html] (this only applies for new installations)
# [Install and configure the HipChat for Bitbucket Cloud integration|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucket/use-the-hipchat-integration-414810551.html#UsetheHipChatintegration-InstallandconfiguretheHipChatforintegration] (note: this step is valid also for a Bitbucket server installation)

h3. Expected Results
The connection to HipChat is created successfully.

h3. Actual Results
The below exception is thrown in the {{atlassian-bitbucket.log}} file:
{noformat}
WARN  [http-nio-7990-exec-4] admin @1TDQ37Jx692x78x1 1r97yov 0:0:0:0:0:0:0:1 "POST /rest/hipchat/integration/latest/installation/complete HTTP/1.1" c.a.p.h.rest.HipChatLinkResource null
{noformat}

{noformat}

fields.description:
h3. Summary
Through the issues below:
- [BSERV-7119|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/BSERV-7119]
- [BSERV-4631|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/BSERV-4631]

We implemented a safety mechanism in case Stash/Bitbucket loses connection to an external management system and removes users from its cache.

This safety mechanism basically consists of:
- In case Stash/Bitbucket loses connection to an external management system, there is a use case that Embedded Crowd will remove that user/group from its cache
- In the past, we would just go ahead and delete that user and its personal data, groups membership, projects/repo permissions etc
- The safety mechanism we apply is that in case that user returns to the LDAP (or the connection is re-established) and is re-synced, we are able to recover its personal data (SSH keys permissions) as well as permissions (global permission, project permission, repository permissions, branch permissions) because as opposed to removing the data from the database straight away, we keep them flagged for a period of time and run a daily job to remove the data that expired.
- *Problem:* there is a use case that doesn't seem to have been covered, though. If the LDAP user was assigned to a local group in Stash/Bitbucket and this user is removed, this local group membership won't be recovered when the user is re-synced from the LDAP.
- *Impact:* developers on that instance won't be able to push code because they will have become unlicensed due to not being in the local {{stash-users}} group

h3. Environment
* Stash 3.11.4
* Configure an External Directory LDAP connection
-- Set [LDAP permission as "Read Only, with Local Groups"|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BitbucketServer/Connecting+Bitbucket+Server+to+an+existing+LDAP+directory#ConnectingBitbucketServertoanexistingLDAPdirectory-LDAPpermission]
-- Add {{stash-users}} as "Default Group Memberships". Users will be added to this group (which is a local group) when they first log in. This will only be done once per user. These groups will be created if they don't already exist, but adding to {{stash-users}} will be the easiest set up as it already contains [Global permissions|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/STASH/Global+permissions] by default as "Stash Users".


h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a LDAP directory with local group
# Synchronise the users and add them to a local group (i.e {{stash-users}})
# Sync up with Stash with the LDAP configured with local groups where the user automatically gets added to {{stash-users}}
# Login with an LDAP user
# Make sure the user has been added to {{stash-users}}
# Remove the user from LDAP
# Sync up Stash/LDAP
# Add user back to LDAP
# Sync

{panel}
(i) *In case you deleted your external directory...*

Notice that if you delete your external directory from Stash/Bitbucket, that behaviour is expected and it is _not_ a bug.
{panel}

h3. Expected Results
Users previously linked to the {{stash-users}} group should come back to Stash/Bitbucket and get all their previous memberships.

Just like we currently do for permissions, personal data and memberships, this membership shouldn't be deleted straight away. 

We should flag them and have them cleaned up later on by the daily job.

h3. Actual Results
All of the users from the LDAP directory are removed from the {{stash-users}} local group and become unlicensed. The membership _is not_ restored.
 
h3.Workaround

*Default Group Memberships option is in use:*
The "Read Only, with Local Groups" option allows you to choose a _Default Group Membership_ option which means:
{quote}
_Users, groups and memberships are retrieved from your LDAP server and cannot be modified in Bitbucket. Users from LDAP can be added to groups maintained in Bitbucket's internal directory._
{quote}

The above is a copy from the application UI. If that's the case for you, in order to restore their licensing status, have the users login to the web interface and they will be added back into {{stash-users}}.

*Default Group Memberships option is not in use:*

You can do that manually using the UI (assign the users to the desired local group). An alternative to do it programmatically using the REST API is described on:
- [Adding 'n' number of users in a Stash group|https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/5703300/adding-n-number-of-users-in-a-stash-group.]

Check out [BSERV-4117|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/BSERV-4117] to obtain a list of the users that have been logging in to your instance recently.
fields.summary: Preserve local group membership data upon loss of connection to external user directory

fields.description:
There is a really good reason to have a "minimum successful build" for branches that are going into product or testing however sometimes branches are made where breaking changes are done during development. In these cases you want to allow to still use pull requests to include code review and other reasons as well to include collaboration on bigger branches.

With the current approach it is not possible to put this requirement on "minimal successful builds" on specific beaches instead it is currently a global setting for the whole repository.

I would suggest to change this so that you could limit this constraint check to only affect the beaches of your choice.
fields.summary: "Minimum successful builds" for pull requests of specific branch
Rename the "Commit Date" column in the repository commits page to "Date"

fields.description: When an external library or repo is added, committed and pushed to a Stash/Bitbucket Server repo as a submodule, the link within the Stash/Bitbucket Server Web GUI takes the visitor to the external location. This means that the referer (referrer) url (Stash/Bitbucket Server) is sent to the external server and is logged. This is poses as a data/information leak.
fields.summary: As a user, I want an external git submodule link to not send referer url as it may pose a information leak.

fields.description:
h3. Summary

When setting up multiple branch permissions with access grants, the access grants will not be effective in allowing the deletion of a branch via the UI. 

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Set up a branch permission for the pattern {{refs/}} with an access grant for "user-1"
# Set up a branch permission for the pattern {{refs/heads/feature}} with an access grant for "user-2"
# Log in as "user-2"
# Attempt to delete a branch matching the {{refs/heads/feature}} pattern (like {{feature/testbranch}})

h3. Expected Results

The branch can be deleted.

h3. Actual Results

An error flag is shown in the UI indicating the branch cannot be deleted due to branch permissions.
 
h3.Solution

Upgrade to Bitbucket Server 4.0 or higher.

h3.Workaround

To work around this issue, delete the branch via git. 
To delete a branch via git you can use the following terminal command: {{git push origin :feature/testbranch}} - Note the ":" (colon) before the branch name.
fields.summary: Branch permissions prevent deleting a branch via UI with multiple permissions set

fields.description:
h3. Summary

Auto-merge toggle can incorrectly be in disabled state in the UI.This is a regression of https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/BSERV-5468.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Go to the Branching Model page for a repository with default settings
# Deselect the Release branch checkbox. _"Enable automatic merging" becomes disabled as expected (as neither condition for auto-merging is met)._
# Now select a Production branch the "Enable automatic merging" checkbox

h3. Expected Results
"Enable automatic merging" checkbox should be enabled.

h3. Actual Results
"Enable automatic merging" checkbox remains disabled

h3.Workaround
You can re-enable by toggling the Release checkbox on and back off again.
fields.summary: Branching model UI bug - auto-merge toggle can incorrectly be in disabled state - Regression

fields.description:
For some of our users the tooltips keep popping up.
An example:
When such a user opens a repository and goes to the branches section next tooltip pops-up:
_"Base branch

Select a different branch to compare how many commits ahead or behind specific branches are relative to the base branch."_

This user can press on "Close", but the next time he will open the branch section again, the pop-up will appear again. Same for other tooltips.

We have tested this for different users on the same system / same browser. Some users have this problem, other users don't.
fields.summary: Tooltip keeps popping up

fields.description:
When I click the Blame button on a file view (e.g. on https://git.example.com/projects/PROJ/repos/my-proj/browse/main.c) I get an error message:

'/usr/bin/git blame --incremental -L 1,+20000 8cbf24ff8d5112....f406bdb16d4cba223 -- main.c' exited with code 128 saying: warning: unable to access '/home/adminuser/.config/git/attributes': Permission denied fatal: file main.c has only 567 lines

Note: The fatal error is filed as BSERV-8135. This report is for the warning.

Issue for this ticket: 
Apparently git gets run with an improperly set HOME, so it tries to read adminuser's .config instead of atlbitbucket's .config. That triggers the permission denied warning.
fields.summary: 'Blame' warning: unable to access '/home/adminuser/.config/git/attributes': Permission denied

fields.description:
When I click the Blame button on a file view (e.g. on https://git.example.com/projects/PROJ/repos/my-proj/browse/main.c) I get an error message:

'/usr/bin/git blame --incremental -L 1,+20000 8cbf24ff8d5112....f406bdb16d4cba223 -- main.c' exited with code 128 saying: warning: unable to access '/home/adminuser/.config/git/attributes': Permission denied fatal: file main.c has only 567 lines

There's a fatal error caused by -L 1,+20000 used with files that are shorter than 20k lines. I see the desire to restrict blame output to e.g. 20000 lines, but I'm afraid the approach used isn't working with this version of Git.
fields.summary: 'Blame' error: fatal: file main.c has only 123 lines

fields.description:
*As a Developer I should be able to annotate a tag with a title and description, thus creating a "Release", so that I can go back and remember the significance of a tag*

*Acceptance Criteria*
* There is a releases link on the left hand side
* And clicking the link navigates the user to the "Releases" page
* And all tags are listed on the "Releases" page
* For each tag, there is the option to create a Release
* For each Release, the user may add a title and description
* And the Release can be created

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
The merge commit message from a pull request is not displayed in the Activity Stream of the Pull Request:

!Pull request-merged log.png|thumbnail!

As described in [Using pull requests in Stash|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/STASH/Using+pull+requests+in+Stash#UsingpullrequestsinStash-Mergingapullrequest] - currently the text that is added for the merge appears between the subject line and the log lines that Stash and Git generate but this is only displayed in the commits itself.

h3. Suggested Solution
 
Display the merge commit message in the Activity Stream
fields.summary: It would be useful in Bitbucket Server for the merge commit message to be displayed in the Activity Stream of the Pull Request

fields.summary: Delete button is sometimes selected by default, sometimes not

fields.description:
If I look at a diff with git-diff(1) or git-show(1), each hunk is marked with the containing function signature like so:

@@ -2886,10 +2824,18 @@ IOReturn AppleKeyStoreUserClient::handleUserClientCommandGated(void* thing1, voi

+ this 
- that

That’s helpful as it informs the context of the change you’re looking at. But if I view a diff in Stash, it doesn’t give me that information (see attached screenshot). I often end up having to click “show more” until I get to the top of the function the change is in, which is tedious. git clearly knows how to identify the scope enclosing a change, so it’d be great if Stash could show me that information.
fields.summary: Stash diff viewer should tell you what function or method you're in

fields.description:
Within Bitbucket you can use a couple of formats to display some README text on the overview page of a repsoitory (possible markup dialects are python markdown, textilem reStructured Text ...) Those README.* files are rendered and displayed on the overview page of the repsoitory.

What I miss here is support of confluence markup as a possible format to be used within this mechanism.

As we are using JIRA (which uses confluence markup) and Bitbucket ((which does not support  confluence markup), our users have to learn/use two different markup/markdown dialects to write something within two different application (although the products are manufactured by the SAME vendor Atlassian)
fields.summary: Confluence Markup Support in Bitbucket

fields.summary: Double dot in Setup screen when integrating with JIRA

fields.description:
h3. Summary

When a user is created on Oracle database according to our documentation:
- [Connecting Bitbucket Server to Oracle|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver/connecting-bitbucket-server-to-oracle-776640379.html]
{quote}
Grant the Bitbucket Server user {{connect}} and {{resource}} roles only. The {{connect}} role is required to set up a connection, while {{resource}} role is required to allow the user to create objects in its own schema.

{code}
CREATE USER <user>
  IDENTIFIED BY <password>
  DEFAULT TABLESPACE USERS
  QUOTA UNLIMITED ON USERS;
GRANT CONNECT, RESOURCE to <user>;
CREATE VIEW <user>.all_objects AS
  SELECT *
  FROM sys.all_objects
  WHERE owner = upper('<user>');
{code}
{quote}

But when the tablespace itself doesn't not have sufficient quota available, the exception thrown in Bitbucket logs are misleading.

h3. Environment
{panel}
Bitbucket with an Oracle database.
{panel}

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Install Bitbucket
# Connect to Oracle
# Make a table with insufficient quota available

h3. Expected Results

A stack trace indicating that the problem is related to insufficient quota available should be thrown.

h3. Actual Results

The below exception is thrown in the {{atlassian-stash.log}} file:
{noformat}
Bitbucket does not have adequate permissions to modify the target database when connected as the specified user. Please check that the user has permission to CREATE and DROP tables and to INSERT and DELETE data. For information about creating a database for use with Bitbucket, please refer to the Bitbucket documentation.
If you continue having issues, get in touch with our support team and we'll help get you up and running.
Hide details
Bitbucket does not have adequate permissions to modify the target database when connected as the specified user. Please check that the user has permission to CREATE and DROP tables and to INSERT and DELETE data. For information about creating a database for use with Bitbucket, please refer to the Bitbucket documentation.
com.atlassian.stash.internal.db.DefaultDatabaseManager.validateConfiguration(DefaultDatabaseManager.java:239)
com.atlassian.stash.internal.migration.DefaultMigrationService.validateConfiguration(DefaultMigrationService.java:85)
sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method)
{noformat}

This makes you believe that the problem is related to permissions.


h3. Workaround

Check the database server logs and allow sufficient quota available for the tablespace.
fields.summary: Misleading error is shown when there is insufficient quota for a table in Oracle

fields.description:
We currently require 1 approval for any pull request to be merged.

I want to configure it so that pull requests against the {{master}} branch require 2 approvals to be merged.

It also we would be nice if I could configure it so that our {{uat}} and {{master}} branches have different pull request rules with regards to JIRA ticket status (understanding that this comes from post-receive hook plugins)
fields.summary: Support different pull request rules per-branch.

fields.description:
I'd like to be able to set (for instance, in Chrome) a "stash" search engine with URL "http://stash.mycompany.com/search?repo=%s" so I could quickly search for a repo on my company's stash/bitbucket server from my browser bar. 

Currently, the search box for repo searching uses a JSON-returning REST search endpoint which can't be utilized by a browser search engine configuration. 

This is already possible with other Atlassian projects:
* Confluence: https://confluence.mycompany.com/dosearchsite.action?queryString=%s
* Jira: https://jira.mycompany.com/secure/QuickSearch.jspa?searchString=%s
fields.summary: provide URL-based searching capability

# Start server in UTC TZ ({{-Duser.timezone=Z}}). It must be a different TZ to what the browser is running. 
# Create a PR. 
# Hover over the 'A moment ago' to see what time is rendered. It will be in UTC. This is expected as all dates and times are rendered in the server's TZ.
# (BUG) Go to the PR list view and find that PR. Hover over the 'A moment ago' to see what time is rendered. It will be the local time *which is incorrect* as all dates and times should be rendered in the server's TZ.

*Expected:* All dates should be rendered in the server's TZ. This is currently necessary because the dates are rendered on the server and client and we need to keep them consistent.

fields.description:
On initial load of a browse page the files and directories are sorted server-side, on subsequent navigation the files and directories are sorted client-side.  There are some inconsistencies with this sort order for non-alphanumeric characters.

To reproduce:

* Browse source for a repo with folders that start with non-alphanumeric characters - for example "AAA" and "\{AAA}"
* click through to a folder
* use "Back" in your browser

Expected results:

* Files/Folders are in the same order

Actual results:

* "\{AAA}" comes first when sorted client-side, "AAA" comes first when sorted server side
fields.summary: File browser sort order inconsistent

fields.description:
This is a suggestion to update the "Application title" during the upgrade from Stash to Bitbucket Server in case it's set as "Stash", since it can lead to some confusion. 

I'm suggesting this as the only case to be updated since, when set to "Stash", it probably means the user never changed or noticed this setting, so it may cause some confusion after the upgrade, as the browser will show the application named as "Stash", and the same will happen to the "Application Navigator".
fields.summary: Update the Application title when upgrading from Stash to Bitbucket Server if title is set as "Stash"

fields.description:
When using the feature 'Delegating Stash authentication to an LDAP directory' with the copy users on login option, users still have the ability to edit their user account details.  In effect this presents a vulnerability whereby one user could spoof another by changing their display name and email address to that of the other user.

While this could be ultimately detected by referral to the username associated with an update this still represents a genuine opportunity for malicious or fraudulent activity to be masked. 

We need a fix that ensures that user profile details are fixed/maintained when using this mode in the same they are when connecting Stash to an existing LDAP Directory and syncing users in a specific user group.
fields.summary: Lock User Account Data in BBServer when using copy on login

It seems like on top of that, there's also a "Thread-Topic" which dictates the subject shown for the thread as a whole, which might be useful if it was set to an Issue Number or something.

fields.description:
Concerns have been raised around the validation of the authorship of Git commits from an audit point of view.  Ie. in the future would we be able to identify with confidence the author of a particular change/commit.

This is because Git requires that the user self enter their name and email address in their local Git configuration (which by default is not setup).  There is no ‘single sign on’ or LDAP integration of the Git tools with any identity authority system.

The authorship information specified on the machine is then added to every commit that user makes.

By default Stash accepts every commit and does not verify or validate that the user submitting (pushing) the commits is the same person recorded in the commit itself.

This raises the possibility that someone could impersonate another person and make a commit under a different name.

It would be very hard to determine who the original committer/author was, as no IP address or machine name information is recorded which could be used to trace this.

In addition, depending on how locked down a repository is, it is possible for someone (or at least the repository administrator) to go back through commit history to either remove a commit that was made, alter it or change the authorship of a commit.

This clearly raises a few concerns from.

It therefore seems prudent that some checks are performed on Stash to govern and control this.

I believe there are some plugins that might help, like the “Yet Another Commit Checker” which can validate that the person pushing the changes is the person recorded in the commit.  Although these could also be switched off at the repository level and so circumvented by the administrator and it does not help with the rewriting of history.

Any plugin would have to work with the Git rebasing mechanism that is being used by teams to bring in changes to their branches.

An additional plugin that would help would be one to enforce that all changes undergo a pull request/code review and that all changes are therefore reviewed and approved by the team/gatekeeper prior to committing.
fields.summary: Possibility for developer spoofing at a git level with BB Server

fields.description:
h3. Summary
When 3.10.0 was released the logic of branch permissions was changed so that "Restrictions should always be applied to achieve the most restrictive subset." A subsequent bug was created [BSERV-7597|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/BSERV-7597], and the permissions were switched back to the way they were originally. Currently you just need permission from any pattern that matches. If one of the patterns denies permission and another one allows it, access is allowed. 


h3. Problem
There are certain cases in which the branch logic that was fixed are necessary. For instance:

You have 3 groups of users: 
- Contractors: who only are allowed to commit to bugfix branches.
- Developers: who are allowed to write anywhere in the repository, except when a release branch is locked down in preparation for release. 
- Admins: Have full permissions and manage release branches.   

Ideally you would want branch permissions set up so that Admins and Developers have the following branch permissions for read and write: {{release/**}}. 

When a branch is frozen for a release a new branch permission would be created for a specific release branch like {{release/2.2.0}} that are assigned to admins only. 


h3. Workarounds

# Currently to achieve permissions that are this granular your best option would be to fork a repository within the same project. Contractors can commit to this fork and create pull requests into the original repo. You will only need to set one branch permission on the original repo for the release branch that is frozen and disallow write permission to the original repo for the Contractors. 
# Another option would be to manually add branch permissions to your Developers for each release branch like this:
{code}
release/2.2.0.0: Admins
master: Developers
release/2.1.*: Developers
release/2.0.*: Developers
release/2.3.*: Developers
release/1.*: Developers
{code}
This is not ideal, because branch permissions have to be set every time a branch is created to prevent the contractors from committing to it. 


h3. Solution:

A way to toggle the logic used by branch permissions. If the default was to the current setting, long time customers wouldn't be affected by upgrades and those that need granular branch permissions could have it when they need it, on a repository by repository basis.
fields.summary: Toggle branch permission logic

fields.description:
Links to commits on {{Commits}} and {{Overview}} tabs of the cross-repository Pull Request may lead to 404 error in some cases.

h2. Steps to reproduce

h6. No write access to the target repo
# Fork a repository you don't have write access to
# Clone the fork on your local machine
# Create a branch, create and push a commit(s)
# Create a Pull Request from that branch to `master` of origin repo
# Go to the {{Commits}} tab
# All commit links will result in 404 when clicked
# If you update the Pull Request with other commits, they will have broken links on both {{Commits}} and {{Overview}} tabs even if the entire page is reloaded unless you click on {{Diff}} tab

h6. With write access to the target repo
# Repeat aforementioned steps until creating the Pull Request
# Create a PR to `master` of origin repo — you'll end up on {{Overview}} tab of Pull Request page, stay there
# Create and push another commit(s) to the source branch
# Click on {{Commits}} tab, but don't refresh entire page
# Last added commit links will result in 404 when clicked
# Same with the added commit links on {{Overview}} tab: they'll remain to be broken unless you click on {{Diff}} tab or reload entire page
fields.summary: Broken commit links in a cross-repository Pull Request

fields.description:
Using the Stash REST API and sending POST or PUT requests, if the JSON payload is not formated correctly the Stash server returns HTTP 500 instead of HTTP 400.

* STEPS TO REPRODUCE
curl  -H "Authorization: Basic ..." -H "Content-Type: application/json" -X PUT -d ' "{hook-url-0" : "some-url"}' 'https://example.com/rest/api/1.0/projects/{projectKey}/repos/{repositorySlug}/settings/hooks/{hookKey}/enabled

Note that the payload is not correct JSON.


* RESULTS
Stash returns
 HTTP/1.1 500 Internal Server Error
 {
    "errors": [
        {
            "context": null,
            "exceptionName": null,
            "message": "An error occurred while processing the request. Check the server logs for more information."
        }
    ]
}


Stash should return,
 400 Bad Request
fields.summary: Malformed JSON should return HTTP 400, not HTTP 500

Today there appears to be no way to add such comments in say the file source view or by navigating the repository, which I think would be very useful.

fields.description:
Stash does not display individual commit comments on the main page.

This behavior is in contrast to making comments on the main 'Diff' pane of a pull request.

The comments made on each individual commit part of a diff, do not display on the main page, but can still be seen after selecting a commit:

Similarly, comments on the main Diff are not visible when selecting an individual commit.

Stash should display ALL comments on the main page, not just the ones made on the main page diff.
fields.summary: Stash pull request does not display and notify individual commit comments on the main page

So the list might look like: • 8b9b9d19747ca872fe026b7cdf6ccf7bb7e59bc0 - Update revision and HTML docs for foo-410 submission (also reflects DI-346, -373, and -397) • - Merge branch 'foo/PR-16914430' …etc.
